form.steps:
1. Kneel on the floor with your knees hip-width apart and your shins flat on the ground. 
2. Place your hands shoulder-width apart or slightly wider, with your fingers pointing forward or slightly outward. 
3. Engage your core and glutes to maintain a straight line from your head to your knees. 
4. Lower your body towards the floor by bending your elbows until your chest touches the floor or reaches a comfortable depth. 
5. Push yourself back up to the starting position by extending your arms, maintaining a straight line from head to knees.

form.Hand Placement: Place your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, with your fingers pointing forward or slightly outward.
form.Elbow Position: Keep your elbows slightly tucked in towards your body during the movement, not flared out to the sides.
form.Body Alignment: Maintain a straight line from your head to your knees throughout the exercise. Don't let your hips sag or your back arch.
form.Core Engagement: Engage your core muscles (abs and lower back) to stabilize your body and prevent your hips from sagging.
form.Breathing: Inhale as you lower your body towards the floor and exhale as you push yourself back up.

commonMistakes.Sagging Hips: Letting your hips sag towards the floor, which indicates weak core engagement.
commonMistakes.Arching Back: Arching your back excessively, which can put stress on your lower back.
commonMistakes.Flaring Elbows: Allowing your elbows to flare out to the sides, which can put stress on your shoulder joints.
commonMistakes.Partial Range of Motion: Not lowering your chest close enough to the floor or not fully extending your arms at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes.Head Position: Letting your head drop or jut forward, which can strain your neck. Keep your head in line with your spine.

comments.Easier Variation: This is an easier variation of the classic push-up. In regular push-ups on your feet, you lift about 70% of your own body weight, but in kneeling push-ups, you only lift about 55% of your body weight.
comments.Progression: Therefore, this exercise variation can serve as a useful training tool to increase your strength until you can do regular push-ups.
comments.Muscle Groups Worked: Kneeling push-ups primarily work the chest, triceps, and front deltoids. They also engage the core muscles for stability.

alternativesAndVariations.Regular Push-Ups: A more challenging variation where you support your body weight on your toes instead of your knees.
alternativesAndVariations.Incline Push-Ups: An easier variation performed with your hands elevated on a bench or step, reducing the amount of body weight you lift.
alternativesAndVariations.Decline Push-Ups: A more challenging variation performed with your feet elevated on a bench or step, increasing the amount of body weight you lift.
alternativesAndVariations.Wall Push-Ups: The easiest variation, performed standing upright and pushing against a wall. This is a good starting point for beginners.
alternativesAndVariations.Diamond Push-Ups: A variation that places more emphasis on the triceps, performed with your hands close together forming a diamond shape with your index fingers and thumbs.

kneeling-push-up.tempo: 2010 (2 seconds lowering, 0 seconds pause at the bottom, 1 second lifting, 0 seconds pause at the top)
